STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
May 19, 2022
Jennifer Trotter
Girlstown Foundation
PO Box 727
Belleville, MI 48111
RE: License #: CB820201144
Guiding Harbor
525 Huron River Drive
Belleville, MI 48111
Dear Ms. Trotter:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
May 11, 2022. An Exit Conference was held with the agency on May 13, 2022. Due to
the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations
of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the MSA and your contract. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248)860-0787.
Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB820201144
Licensee Name: Girlstown Foundation
Licensee Address: 525 Huron River Drive
Belleville, MI 48111
Licensee Telephone #:
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Jennifer Trotter, Designee
Name of Facility: Guiding Harbor
Facility Address: 525 Huron River Drive
Belleville, MI 48111
Facility Telephone #: (734) 697-7242
Original Issuance Date: 05/20/1989
Service Types: PLACE CHILDREN FOR ADOPTION
CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
EVALUATE APPLICANTS FOR ADOPTION
CONTRACT-ADOPTION
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION – A. Consultant
Date of On-site Inspection(s):05/05/2022-05/11/2022

Reviewed

in foster care since last inspection 0 0

The following required records were on file and available for review:

Total No. No. Visited
No. of licensed foster homes 10 3
No. of unlicensed relatives homes 23 3
No. of independent living youth

Foster Parents 3
Foster Children 10
Birth Parents
Independent Living Youth
Relatives 3
Adoptive Parents
Others (please identify person interviewed by role)
3

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12202 Policy and procedures.
(1) An agency shall have and follow written policies and
procedures for all of the following:
(d) Staff qualifications.
The agency requires annual ICHATs and central registry
clearances.
Five of five employee records reviewed where the employee
was employed for over a year did not show compliance:
 The employee’s annual ICHAT or central registry
clearance was completed either over a year with respect
to the last one completed, or it was missing.
R 400.12208 Job descriptions.
(1) An agency shall have a current written job description for
each staff position.
One of seven new employee records reviewed did not show a
job description for the employee identified as an Intern.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(b) Verification of education.
(c) Work history.
(d) Three references obtained from persons who are
unrelated to the staff person.
One of seven employee records reviewed did not show
documentation of (b)-(d) for the employee identified as an
intern.
(d) is a Repeat Violation- Interim 2021.
4

R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(e) A record of any convictions other than minor traffic
violations from either of the following:
(i) The Michigan state police or the equivalent state or
Canadian provincial law enforcement agency where the person
usually resides.
(ii) An entity accessing either Michigan state police
records or equivalent state or Canadian provincial law
enforcement agency where the person usually resides.
Two of seven new employee records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One employee’s ICHAT was completed on 6/15/2021,14
days after the employee’s 6/1/2021 date of hire.
 A second employee’s ICHAT was completed on
7/1/2021, almost three months after the employee’s
4/19/2021 date of hire.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(f) If the employee has criminal convictions, the chief
administrator or his or her designee shall complete a written
evaluation of the convictions that addresses the nature of the
conviction, the length of time since the conviction, and the
relationship of the conviction to regulated activity.
(h) Documentation from the department that the person has not
been named in a central registry case as the perpetrator of child
abuse or neglect in Michigan or in any state where the person
lived in the 5 years preceding hire.
(f):
Two of seven new employee records reviewed showed the
agency’s administrator initiated/stamped the employee’s ICHAT
document, but it did not show a written statement related to the
respective employee’s 2016 and 2017 conviction, as required by
the rule.
(h):
One of seven new employee records reviewed did not show
documentation of a central registry clearance.
5

Repeat Violation- Renewal 2020.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months after the
staff member assumes his or her current responsibilities. After
the initial evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted
each year.
Three of 12 employee records reviewed showed the employee’s
written evaluation was completed late with respect to the
employee’s performance evaluation due date:
 One was due by 11/26/2021 and completed on
12/21/2021.
 A second was due by 12/1/2021 and completed on
12/12/2021.
 A third was due by 11/24/2021 and completed on
12/12/2021.
R 400.12306 Application request.
(4) An agency shall document that the licensee has been given
an application for renewal of the license not less than 60
calendar days before the expiration date of the license.
Three of four open foster home records reviewed did not show
documentation that the foster home was provided an application
at least 60 days before the foster home’s respective 9/9/2021;
2/16/2022; and 5/9/2022 license expiration date.
R 400.12311 Foster parent/agency agreement.
(2) The foster parent/agency agreement shall contain all of the
following provisions:
(e) The role of the lawyer guardian ad litem and the court.
A review of the agency’s foster parent/agency agreement
related to the four foster home records reviewed did not show
documentation of (e) as required by the rule.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
6

Three of four open foster home records reviewed did not show
compliance as required by the rule:
 Two were submitted on the day the license was expiring,
2/16/2022 and 5/9/2022 respectively.
 A third was submitted 9 days before the license
expiration date, on 8/31/2021.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2021; Renewal 2020.
R 400.12325 License recommendation.
(1) An agency shall recommend to the department the
appropriate licensing action consistent with facts contained in
the foster home evaluation and any special evaluations.
One of four open foster home records reviewed showed the
recommendation was not based on facts within the evaluation.
The recommendation was made on 8/31/2021, before the
evaluation was approved on 9/16/2021.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(d) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children are
interviewed, their last names shall not be included in the report.
One of one special evaluation records reviewed did not show
clear documentation of the interviewer for all interviews, or
where/how the respective workers were interviewed.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(f) Notification to the parents, referral source, lawyer
guardian ad litem, and courts when applicable, of the change in
placement.
Two of four closed foster child records reviewed did not show
compliance as required by the rule
7

R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the child in a
foster home, then both of the following shall be documented
before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up to the
time of the change in placement and the needs that remain to
be met.
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
One of four closed foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of (a) and (b), as required by the rule.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 12 months before
placement or a new physical examination shall be completed
within 30 calendar days after placement.
One of six open foster child records reviewed showed the child’s
medical exam was due by 8/27/2021 and completed 18 days
late on 9/13/2021.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2021.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any treatment
required for each child who is 4 years of age and older,
including both of the following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be completed not
more than 90 calendar days after placement.
Two of six open foster child records reviewed showed:
 One child’s initial dental was due by 10/7/2021 and
completed 16 days late on 10/23/2021.
8

 A second child’s dental was due by 11/2/2021 and was
completed 83 days late on 1/22/2022. The agency
reported this delay was due to a lack of cooperation by
the relative, inclusive of the relative refusing to allow the
foster care worker to take the child for the dental
examination.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2021, Renewal 2020.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Five of 22 updated service plans (USP) reviewed were late (The
records related to two open foster child records, and two open
independent youth records):
 One foster child’s 5/18/2021-11/18/2021 USP was
completed 4 days late on 8/19/2021.
 A second foster child’s 8/21/2021-11/18/2021 USP was
completed 1 day late on 11/19/2021.
 An independent living youth’s 8/24/2021-11/21/2021
USP was completed 2 days late on 11/23/2021.
 A second independent living youth’s 10/14/2021-
1/11/2022 USP was completed 8 days late on
1/19/2022. This youth’s 1/12/202-4/11/2021 USP was
completed 16 days late on 4/27/2022.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2021, Renewal 2020.
R 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R 400.12418(2)(a),
shall include all of the following information:
(h) The child management plan to be used by the foster
parent.
One of five initial service plans (ISP) reviewed did not show
documentation of (h) as required by the rule.
R 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R 400.12418(2)(b),
shall include all of the following information:
9

(g) A child management plan which includes any changes
made since the previous plan and which is to be used by the
foster parents.
Two of 22 USPs reviewed (related to one open foster child’s
record) did not show compliance as required by the rule.
R 400.12505 Supervision.
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum supervision:
(a) Face-to-face contact between the social service worker
and the youth in independent living at least once each month at
a youth's place of residence.
Two of two independent living records reviewed did not show a
November 2021 placement visit related to one youth; or a
January 2022 placement visit related to another youth.
R 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a written
adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family signing an
adoption application and prior to approving a family for adoption.
Two of three family adoption evaluation records reviewed
showed an adoption evaluation was not completed within 90
days of the respective family’s 4/6/2021 and 7/26/2021
application date.
R 400.12607 Agency recommendation.
(4) An agency shall provide the applicants for adoption with a
signed and dated copy of the evaluation and recommendation
upon its completion.
Two of three adoptive family evaluation records reviewed did
not show compliance as required by the rule.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
10

ISEP 6.19 (5) (c) Assessments and Service Plans, Content (commitment 69).
Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker's supervisor, the parent(s}, and the child(ren),
if of age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both
are not available or decline to sign the plan, the service
plan shall include an explanation of the steps taken to
involve them and shall identify any follow-up actions to be
taken to secure their participation in services.
Four of 27 service plans reviewed did not show compliance:
 One child’s 5/18/2021-8/12/2021; 8/13/2021-11/12/2021
and 11/13/2021-2/12/2022 USP did not show
documentation of the birth parent’s signature.
 A second child’s 11/19/2021-2/16/2022 USP did not
show document of the child’s 16-year-old sibling’s
signature.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
ADM 300 Child adoption assessment addendum.
The DHS-606, Child Adoption Assessment Addendum, must be
used to update the DHS-1927, Child Adoption Assessment, on
an annual basis if the child has not been placed for adoption.
Five of seven child adoption records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One child’s Child Adoption Assessment (CAA) was due
by 4/29/2021 and completed 25 days late on 5/24/2021.
 A second child’s CAA was due by 8/14/2021 and
completed 5 days late on 8/19/2021.
 A third child’s CAA was due by 5/4/2021 and completed 6
days late on 5/10/2021.
 A fourth child’s CAA was due by 6/21/2021 and
completed 32 days late on 7/23/2021.
 A fifth child’s annual CAA was due by 7/13/2021 and
completed six months late on 1/12/2022.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2021.
11

ADM 330 Quarterly progress reports.
Quarterly progress reports (DHHA-614) are to be completed
each quarter.
Three of seven child adoption records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One child’s 12/9/2021-3/9/2022 quarterly adoption
progress report was completed 12 days late on
3/21/2022.
 A second child’s 1/22/2022- 4/22/2022 quarterly adoption
progress report was completed 7 days late on 4/29/2022.
 A third child’s closing adoption quarterly progress report
was not documented.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2021, Renewal 2020.
ADM 710 State Ward Tracking System & Registration on Michigan
Adoption Resource Exchange.
For children who have an identified adoptive parent:
 The child must be registered on hold on the MARE public
website within 60 calendar days of receipt of the court
order terminating parental rights or the date of
acceptance of the adoption referral, whichever is later
One of seven adoption child records reviewed showed the
child’s MARE registration date of 12/17/2021 was more than 60
days of the child’s 6/30/2021 case acceptance.
Discharging Children from MARE Tracking:
 When a child is placed for adoption, the child’s adoption
worker must submit within 14 calendar days of receipt,
the PCA 320, Order Placing Child to discharge the child
from MARE tracking.
Three of three finalized adoption records reviewed did not show
documentation of the child’s MARE removal.
ADM 980 Closing Documentation.
Adoption Closing Summary
A copy of the closing summary must be sent within 14 calendar
days of the adoption finalization date to the foster care worker
and the Department of Health and Services (DHHS) adoption
monitor for purchase of service cases for inclusion in the child’s
permanent record
12

Two of three finalized adoption records reviewed showed the
child’s closing summary(DHHS 222) was completed more than
14 days after the child’s respective 7/30/2021 and 12/20/2021
finalization date.
Closing Letter to Family:
The DHS-607, Adoptive Family Closing Letter form, must be
sent to the family outlining the changes they can expect in
coming weeks and any available future services.
Two of three finalized adoption records reviewed did not show
documentation of the DHHS-607 sent to the adoptive family.
FOM 722-6B Family Team Meeting.
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents, caretakers,
foster parents, children, youth, and may also include extended
family, friends, neighbors, community-based service providers,
community representatives, tribal representatives, for Indian
children, or other professionals involved with the family.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using the
FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must be
completed for each type of meeting
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the required time
frames as out lined in the following table.
One of six open foster child records reviewed, and one of two
open independent living youth records reviewed did not show
compliance:
A foster child’s:
 Record did not show an FTM for the child’s 7/31/2021-
10/28/2021 and 1/27/2022-4/25/2022 USP.
 This child’s semi-annual transition meeting due by
1/9/2022 was completed late on 2/22/2022.
An independent living (IL) youth’s:
 Record did not show an FTM for the youth’s 11/22/2021-
2/22/2022 USP. One was completed after the period on
2/24/2022.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2021, Renewal 2020.
FOM 722-08 Case Service Plans- Overview, Types, And Timeframes.
Supervisor Approval:
13

The supervisor must approve all case service plans within 14
days of the end of the report period.
Six of 27 services plans reviewed did not show compliance:
 One open IL youth’s 5/26/2021-8/23/2021 USP
completed on 8/23/2021 was approved 1 days late on
9/7/2021.
 A second open IL youth’s 4/27/2021-7/23/2021 USP
completed on 7/23/2021 was approved 12 days late on
8/18/2021.
 A third for an open foster child’s 9/8/2021-12/6/2021 USP
completed 12/6/2021 was approved 78 days late on
3/8/2022.
 A fourth for an open foster child’s 7/3/2021-10/28/2021
USP completed 10/28/2021 was approved 4 days late on
11/15/2021. This child’s 10/29/2021-1/26/2022 USP
completed on 1/26/2022 was approved 2 days late on
2/11/2022.
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans.
Agreement and Signature:
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable:
 Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court
ordered caregivers.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
Four of 27 service plans reviewed did not show compliance:
 One child’s 5/18/2021-8/15/2021 treatment plan,
approved 8/26/2021, was not signed by the caregiver
until 10/22/2021. This child’s 8/16/2021-11/12/2021 was
not signed by the caregiver.
 A second child’s 7/31/2021-10/28/2021 treatment plan,
approved on 11/15/2021, was not signed by the
caregiver. This treatment plan was not signed by the
youth and birth parent until 12/30/2021 and/ 1/19/2022
respectively.
 A third child’s 11/19/2021-2/16/2021 treatment plan,
approved on 3/2/2022, was not signed by the caregiver.
Repeat Violation-Interim 2021- Cited under 722-08C
14

FOM 722-8E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
Completion Requirements:
The caseworker must complete the DHS-69, Foster
Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary, and upload to
MiSACWIS within the timeframe required for the specified
change.
 Within three business days of foster care or juvenile
justice program or case closure.
Two of four closed foster child records, and one of three closed
independent living records reviewed did not show that the
DHHS-69 was completed within three business days of the
respective child’s and youth’s 6/17/2021: 8/20/2021 and
1/17/2022 case closure date.
FOM 801-03 Medical Passports.
Updated Medical Passport:
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
 Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary
court ward; Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement;
and at reunification.
 The child’s foster care provider: At or prior to each
placement and quarterly.
Three of six open foster child record reviewed did not show
consistent documentation of quarterly medical passports as
required by the policy.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2021.
FOM 802-2 Mental and Behavioral Health.
All children entering foster care are required to have a mental
health screening within 30 days of removal.
Two of six open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of a health screening, as required by the policy.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R400.12209(1) Orientation and training.
15

 The agency was apprised its documentation of the worker’s 16 hours or
plus of training shall not be represented as occurring in one day.
R400.12324(2)(b) Reevaluation
 The agency is apprised it shall consistently assess and document family
member’s weaknesses, and document side effects of all medications for
family members.
FOM 722-6H Overview and Quality visit standard:
 The agency was apprised to be mindful of this standard and its
documentation requirements for each home visit, so as to ensure
consistent documentation of the home visit and the worker’s engagement
and interaction with the caregiver, as well as the child.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 Nothing this Inspection.
16

EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
AND
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2021 Interim inspection where it
received the following rule violations:
 R400.12205(5)-Required staff.
 R400.12209(1)-Orientation and training.
 R400.12212(1)(d)- Required staff.
 R400.12324(8)-Reevaluation.
 R400.12404(7)(a)-(j)-Placement.
 R400.12413(1)(c)(ii)-Medical and dental policy.
 R400.12413(1)(d)(i)-Medical and dental policy.
 R400.12413(1)(f)(i)-Medical and dental policy.
 R400.12413(2) -Medical and dental policy.
 R400.12418(2)(a) & (b)- Development of services plans.
 R400.12504(1)-Eligibility requirements.
 R400.12504(2)(b)(d)(e)- Eligibility requirements.
 R400.12509(3)(a)(i)-(xi)-Independent living record.
 R400.12510(2)-Independent contract.
 SRM 103- In-service training.
 SRM 200- Security Awareness training.
 FOM 722-05-MISACWIS Case Documentation.
 FOM 722-06B- Family Team Meeting.
 FOM 722-08C- Foster Care Parent Agency Treatment Plan and Service
Agreement. (Signatures).
 FOM 802-Mental health screening.
 ADM300- Child Adoption Assessment.
 ADM 330 Quarterly Adoption Progress Reports
 ADM 400- MARE Registration.
The agency made some progress with that corrective action plan but was not
completely successful with the corrective plan. The agency received repeat violations
this inspection, as indicated in this report. The agency attributed some of this to worker
turnover.
DCWL ANALYST ISSUES ADDRESSED:
The agency received three safety alerts:
Safety Alert #1 received on 4/21/2022:
Concern:
The relative refused a walkthrough of the home to determine if there were any
17

safety concerns. The relative indicated her bedroom was off limits and has never been
viewed by the agency.
Resolution:
The agency’s licensing department reported it had completed a home visit with the
relative on 11/11/2021 for the purpose of completing a 3130A and the licensing worker
viewed the relative’s bedroom during a tour of the home for completing the 3130A.
There were no home concerns noted in the 3130A. The agency reported the licensure
process has since closed due to the relative’s lack of participation in the process and
desire not to be licensed. The agency’s foster care worker (FCW) had visited the home
on 4/21/22; and met with the child in his bedroom. The relative disclosed to the FCW
that she did not let the Analyst into the home because she has a hole in the roof that is
located in an unused bedroom (the agency attached photos to the safety alert showing
the holes). A Safety Plan was created with the relative that no household members will
use this bedroom until repairs are made. The relative was seeking quotes from a
contractor so that resources could be secured for fixing the roof.
Safety Alert #2 received on 5/6/2022.
Concern:
The child placed in the home does not have a bed. The child placed in the home is
currently residing across the street with a relative. There are concerns regarding why
the child is not residing in her current placement full-time.
Resolution:
A safety plan has been put in place and signed by the relative/foster parent and her
daughter/substitute caregiver across the street. The plan states that the child will sleep
in her room at the foster home a minimum of five nights per week and can spend the
night in the home of the relative substitute care provider up to two nights per week. Any
additional overnights must to approved by foster care. The plan will be monitored by the
foster care worker and both relatives during monthly foster home visits. The
relative/foster parent reported on 5/11/2022 that she lied to the Analyst because she
didn’t want anyone in her business anymore. She said the bed was not taken across the
street; it was moved upstairs while the bedroom was being painted. The bed has since
been moved back into the child's bedroom and assembled (a photo was included by the
agency showing the bed in the bedroom). A special investigation was already underway
for the relative/foster parent for previous allegations; and additional finding of insufficient
bedding was being included in the ongoing investigation (2022C0630519).
Safety Alert # 3 received:5/13/2022:
Concern:
All of the rooms in the home were not viewed. The relative did not allow a visit to her
bedroom or the basement.
Resolution:
18

The agency foster care worker and supervisor visited the relatives’ home on 5/13/22 to
complete a safety inspection; and discussed issues of the Safety Alert. They
encouraged the relative to contact the agency when in doubt about who is authorized to
come into the home. The agency staff viewed the bedrooms in the home. The couple
currently are not sleeping in their bedroom; they sleep in the living room. Their
bedroom, which contains a queen size bed, is currently used for storage of boxes and
other items. The room is kept locked. There is another bedroom that is not occupied by
any family members; and it is currently being used to store items that belonged to the
relatives’ deceased daughter. A third bedroom is being used by the three boys. A fourth
bedroom is occupied by their sister.
The relatives’ basement was also viewed during the agency’s 5/13/2022 home visit. The
basement is only used as storage for items (e.g., Toys & bikes) that mostly belong to
the children. There were no concerns noted in the basement. The agency provided
photos of the basement. The agency is encouraged to work with the relatives around,
storage issues, so that they can all utilized their bedrooms for sleeping.
Concern:
Please ensure safety precautions are being used for the outdoor pool.This was not
verified due to the basement door being locked.
Resolution:
The pool area in the backyard was viewed during the agency’s 5/13/2022 home visit.
The backyard contains an above ground pool with a fence around it with three
entrances. The entrances are secured with locks. The children are reported to not be
allowed into the area without adult supervision. The pool has not yet been prepared for
the season. The agency provided photos showing the pool, its fence around, and
security locks.
VI. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes, rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
